abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Investment Fund Project is
            assessed as satisfactory with likely sustainability. The
            positive lessons learned were: a) effective management is a
            necessary condition for efficient operations; b)
            accountability to government proved to be beneficial and
            decisive for the Guatemala Social Investment Fund's
            (FIS's) operations; c) social assistance subprojects
            have different technical requirements than infrastructure
            subprojects for formulation; d) the community organization
            program and the departmental offices helped FIS to gain
            institutional credibility, improved subproject quality, and
            increased the potential for collaboration with local
            organizations; as well as achieving closer relations with
            poor rural communities; e) the on-site exchange of
            experience and information between social funds produces
            good results, and study tours should be strongly supported
            by IBRD. Negative lessons learned include: a) the IBRD
            should have supervised FIS closely and with greater
            frequency; b) the traditional social fund subproject
            processing cycle, procedures, and internal controls are
            essential to efficient FIS operations; c) the outside
            creation and imposition of new organizations on communities
            is not recommended; d) community training in subproject
            operations and maintenance is critical to subproject
            sustainability; and e) to be effective, studies should be
            based on genuine institutional interests and needs, terms of
            reference should clearly define objectives and expected
            outputs, contracting should be timely, and a system should
            be in place for result dissemination.
